currentDoc:
How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important par

 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

Limiting screen time is an important part of this.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work effic

Limiting screen time is an important part of this.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health.

That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases whe

That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activit

That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can he

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens ar

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.

Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less)

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.

 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

I

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.

 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives.

That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, treat screen

Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, treat screen time like you would anyth

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, treat screen time like you would anything else that can affect yo

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have treat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health.

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen titreat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen time can affect you phytreat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health.

That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen time can affect you physical and mental heatreat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health.

Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen time can affect you physical and mental health, so treat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health. MOn

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen time can affect you physical and mental health, so treat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health. Monitor and examine ho

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen time can affect you physical and mental health, so treat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health. Monitor and examine how it effects you. List th

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen time can affect you physical and mental health, so treat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health. Monitor and examine how it effects you. List the benefits and negative

If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen time can affect you physical and mental health, so treat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health. Monitor and examine how it effects you. List the benefits and negatives , and you will be able to discover what you can do to integrate screen use into your life while minimizing any health effects. This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen time can affect you physical and mental health, so treat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health. Monitor and examine how it effects you. List the benefits and negatives , and you will be able to discover what you can do to integrate screen use into your life while minimizing any health effects. How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen time can affect you physical and mental health, so treat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health. Monitor and examine how it effects you. List the benefits and negatives , and you will be able to discover what you can do to integrate screen use into your life while minimizing any health effects. How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen time can affect you physical and mental health, so treat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health. Monitor and examine how it effects you. List the benefits and negatives , and you will be able to discover what you can do to integrate screen use into your life while minimizing any health effects. And keep up to date with new studies and new technologies

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen time can affect you physical and mental health, so treat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health. Monitor and examine how it effects you. List the benefits and negatives , and you will be able to discover what you can do to integrate screen use into your life while minimizing any health effects. And keep up to date with new studies and new technologies; you may learn things

 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen time can affect you physical and mental health, so treat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health. Monitor and examine how it effects you. List the benefits and negatives , and you will be able to discover what you can do to integrate screen use into your life while minimizing any health effects. And keep up to date with new studies and new technologies; you may learn things which cause you to re

Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen time can affect you physical and mental health, so treat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health. Monitor and examine how it effects you. List the benefits and negatives , and you will be able to discover what you can do to integrate screen use into your life while minimizing any health effects. And keep up to date with new studies and new technologies; you may learn things which cause you to re-evaluate your curr

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen time can affect you physical and mental health, so treat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health. Monitor and examine how it effects you. List the benefits and negatives , and you will be able to discover what you can do to integrate screen use into your life while minimizing any health effects. And keep up to date with new studies and new technologies; you may learn things which cause you to re-evaluate your current usage. And above all else; don't rely

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.

Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen time can affect you physical and mental health, so treat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health. Monitor and examine how it effects you. List the benefits and negatives , and you will be able to discover what you can do to integrate screen use into your life while minimizing any health effects. And keep up to date with new studies and new technologies; you may learn things which cause you to re-evaluate your current usage. And above all else; don't rely on screentime activ

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen time can affect you physical and mental health, so treat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health. Monitor and examine how it effects you. List the benefits and negatives , and you will be able to discover what you can do to integrate screen use into your life while minimizing any health effects. And keep up to date with new studies and new technologies; you may learn things which cause you to re-evaluate your current usage. And above all else; don't rely on screentime activities to provide you

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen time can affect you physical and mental health, so treat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health. Monitor and examine how it effects you. List the benefits and negatives , and you will be able to discover what you can do to integrate screen use into your life while minimizing any health effects. And keep up to date with new studies and new technologies; you may learn things which cause you to re-evaluate your current usage. And above all else; don't rely on screentime activities to provide you with everything (w

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen time can affect you physical and mental health, so treat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health. Monitor and examine how it effects you. List the benefits and negatives , and you will be able to discover what you can do to integrate screen use into your life while minimizing any health effects. And keep up to date with new studies and new technologies; you may learn things which cause you to re-evaluate your current usage. And above all else; don't rely on screentime activities to provide you with everything (work, entertainment

How Worried Should We Be About Screen Time During the Pandemic?

The coronavirus pandemic ended the screen time debate: Screens won. We all now find ourselves on our screens for school, for work and for connecting with family and friends during this time of social distancing and increased isolation.

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen time can affect you physical and mental health, so treat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health. Monitor and examine how it effects you. List the benefits and negatives , and you will be able to discover what you can do to integrate screen use into your life while minimizing any health effects. And keep up to date with new studies and new technologies; you may learn things which cause you to re-evaluate your current usage. And above all else; don't rely on screentime activities to provide you with everything (work, entertainment, social interacti

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen time can affect you physical and mental health, so treat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health. Monitor and examine how it effects you. List the benefits and negatives , and you will be able to discover what you can do to integrate screen use into your life while minimizing any health effects. And keep up to date with new studies and new technologies; you may learn things which cause you to re-evaluate your current usage. And above all else; don't rely on screentime activities to provide you with everything (work, entertainment, social interaction). Variety is als

But should we be worried about this excessive screen use right now? Or should we finally get over it and embrace the benefits of our digital devices?

---

In my opinion, the reasoning that existed before the pandemic should still apply. Namely that screen time should be monitored, and that limiting your screen time is best for both mental and physical health. 
The science shows that too much screen time contributes to obesity, diabetes and hypertension.
 It can cause eye strain, disrupt your mental state, and alter your sleep patterns. That last one is very important, as uninterrupted sleep is an absolute requirement for fighting viruses and to speed up our healing responses. If there is one good thing that has come out of the pandemic it is increased awareness of health, and a new focus on maintaining and improving health. Limiting screen time is an important part of this. 

This is not to say that we should give up on screen altogether. They are an important tool for work efficiency, social connection, and overall entertainment. The main point is a balance must be found.
Do you think you're spending too much time on your screen?
 Then you probably are. Like anything else, technology can become excessive and unhealthy if not properly moderated. Exploring other alternatives in cases where screen related activities have taken over can help you learn where screens are essential to you, and where you could give them up (or use them less) for alternatives. 

In short, studies have shown that screen time can affect you physical and mental health, so treat screen time like you would anything else that can affect you health. Monitor and examine how it effects you. List the benefits and negatives , and you will be able to discover what you can do to integrate screen use into your life while minimizing any health effects. And keep up to date with new studies and new technologies; you may learn things which cause you to re-evaluate your current usage. And above all else; don't rely on screentime activities to provide you with everything (work, entertainment, social interaction). Variety is always the healt
